Once your chickens know their pen they'll return on their own in the evening.  It's good to train them with treats that you ONLY provide inside the pen.  When mine see me coming first they run to see what I've got, then they race me to the pen.  (They're very curious, they'll always want to see what you're doing.)

Depending on the breed they can easily fly IF they want to.  Some chickens can't be kept in but they will come home at dusk.  Cover the fence if you have flyers - even if you clip wings which does not injure them, flyers will definitely keep flying.  Heavy birds will fly less and shorter distances.  Real flyers will roost in the trees near the coop.

Check out the town of Stonington, CT, where the enlightened town officials have interpreted the zoning regulations to forbid the keeping of chickens--since chickens are apparently not "fowl".

All this started by a sixth-grade kid who raised prize-winning bantams for a 4H club project:

www.thewesterlysun.com/news/local/article_41076908-e8c3-11de-8457-001cc4...

QUOTE from above article:
The zoning ordinance states that, "dogs, cats, fowl or other compatible with cohabitation with humans may be kept on the minimum lot area." Londregan decided, however, that chickens don't fit the bill.

"Chickens do not cohabitate with humans," he wrote. "Other birds, such as parakeets, canaries, etc., are compatible with cohabitation with humans."
END QUOTE

Compare this to forward-thinking cities, including NY and Chicago and just about every city in California, where a limited number of hens can be raised. We have 10 chickens. My advice is handle them when they are babies...it makes them friendly, and use organic feed. We use a tonic to keep parasites away:

1 cup apple cider vinegar
2 cloves garlic
1 tsp cayenne pepper

Add this to their water (a 1/4 cup to a gallon). Store the tonic in the refrigerator and add it every time you change their water.

It seems to work. Regardless, it is a healthy tonic and the chickens love it!

Chickens are way better than dogs.  I feel sorry for dog in the backyard waiting for something to do all the time.  Play with a dog an hour, and the dog will wonder why not all the time.  Chickens are fine all day by themselves.  We get eggs everyday and give many to neighbors who might hear them on occasion and consider calling the city (some are allowed but there are restrictions).  Neighbors also tend to them while we are gone. For awhile if we did not get them put up by dusk they would fly up into a tree.  I left them up there a few times until a raccoon got some.  Now we nudge them out of the tree if necessary (of late they go to "bed" by themselves). You better have a lock of sorts that a raccoon cannot figure out -- we had that problem too.  The chicks cost $2.  You know what my vet bill is if a chicken gets sick or something? $2. In this city people spend thousands on various issues that dogs and cats have.  These pets are easy and pay for themselves.  They can be noisy on occasion but usually less than 15 minutes.  Kids love to play with them and get the eggs everyday.  I know rats and mice will come for the food but that is not different than any other outside pet who is fed outside.  (A rooster is not required to have eggs by the way.)  We have not had a hawk attack yet, but we saw one once.  If it gets one I might put up some fishing line or some such to spook it away and maybe replace the chicken for $2.  Did I mention the food costs chicken feed?

Substituting piles of money for intelligent political discourse is not my idea of a sane democratic process. If the dollars were spent to encourage and allow reasoned arguments, I would agree with Mr. Douthat's analysis. But in the real world, the influx of dollars is intended to drown out reason with the destructive screaming noise of negative campaign ads. Sadly, in that same real world, history tells us that such ads work.

How often was there an obvious correlation of a candidate's vote total to the amount of dollars spent? And what kind of democracy is that?

Admittedly, in the GOP primary races one candidate began with vastly more resources and would have won more easily but for some Super-PACs closing the gap; leveling the financial playing field (if only a little). But if this primary season represents Ross Douthat's idea of a healthy political process, count me in dissent.

Still in the real world, I accept that Adelson, Freiss, the Koch brothers and others will always have more influence and power than guys like me with my $30,000 gross annual income. I'm okay with that. I am not okay with the gross perversion of the political process in which election results are so blatantly for sale, whether to corporations or individuals.

Citizens United did not infect an otherwise pure and disease-free system. But injecting a massive overdose of poison did not produce the cure that Mr. Douthat pronounces.
